ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Math& Philosophy majors should definitely take this course, as it's information that you should know. If you haven't taken set theory and a higher-level logic course, probably don't take it, as even someone with that background will have a hard time following some of the proofs. The professor is clear and will help you understand things, but he's a bit dry. It won't be the most exciting course you'll take, and it does need some restructuring, but M&P majors will want to know what's taught here.

Whittle is a decent lecturer -- organized, to-the-point, and clear -- a rarity in the philosophy department. That said, discussion did tend to suffer a bit simply because the material was so dense/technical. Workload very reasonable.
Highly recommended for students with a decent background in logic who want to learn more about diverse topics in philosophy of math.

A challenging and technical survey of a variety of ideas in the philosophy of maths. Even with a strong background in math& in logic (for an undergraduate, at least), I found that some of the papers went over my head. Prof. Whittle is awkward, and the class was sometimes awkward, but he is very effective at crystallizing the main points of each weekâs paper into understandable arguments. This means that the course is weirdly skewed towards being a lecture, and the large course size early on didnât help with that. Frankly, I donât think that the lecture-y style is too bad, although it is confusing that 30% of your grade is based on participation when discussion is sort of secondary. If youâre interested in the material, then you should take itâif you donât understand some of the papers, then thatâs not a huge problemâbut you should be aware that it will be challenging. Donât take it on a whim, and avoid it if you lack background in logic.
Good course overall. Notice that the course title is "Topics in Philosophy of Math." If you are looking for a comprehensive introductory course, look elsewhere.
A compelling but difficult course, Philosophy of Math is only for those really interested in the subject. That said, for interested students, it's a valuable course.
